questions.article: The National Heritage Fellowship was created to honor exceptional folk and traditional artists in the United States for their ______. The jazz violinist and guitarist Claude "Fiddler" Williams was chosen for the fellowship because he has contributed so much to the arts.
questions.question: Which choice completes the test with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: achievements

options.name: B
options.content: suspicious

options.name: C
options.content: assumptions

options.name: D
options.content: predictions

questions.correct: achievements

questions.article: Domesticated thousands of years ago in South America, the chili pepper deviates structurally from the wild plant it is descended from. Maize (corn), another domesticated crop from the Americas, doesn’t closely resemble any wild plant, and genetic research only recently ______ its ancestor to be teosinte grass.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: expanded

options.name: B
options.content: revealed

options.name: C
options.content: encouraged

options.name: D
options.content: petitioned

questions.correct: revealed

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Virginia Woolf’s 1919 novel Night and Day. The text describes a gathering of aspiring young artists and intellectuals.

One person after another rose, and, as with an ill-balanced axe, attempted to hew out his conception of art a little more clearly, and sat down with the feeling that, for some reason which he could not grasp, his strokes had gone awry. As they sat down they turned almost invariably to the person sitting next them, and rectified and continued what they had just said in public.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the figurative phrase “hew out” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Visualize

options.name: B
options.content: Define

options.name: C
options.content: Contract

options.name: D
options.content: Emulate

questions.correct: Define

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Betty Smith's 1943 novel A Tree Grows in Brooklyn. Francie, a young girl, visits the library often.

Francie thought that all the books in the world were in that library and she had a plan about reading all the books in the world. She was reading a book a day in alphabetical order and not skipping the dry ones. She remembered that the first author had been Abbott. She had been reading a book a day for a long time now and she was still in the B’s. Already she had read about bees and buffalos, Bermuda vacations and Byzantine architecture. For all her enthusiasm, she had to admit that some of the B's had been hard going. But Francie was a reader.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To illustrate Francie's enjoyment of an unusual topic.

options.name: B
options.content: To explain why Francie prefers reading over other activities.

options.name: C
options.content: To portray Francie's determination to meet a goal.

options.name: D
options.content: To describe a book that Francie greatly admires.

questions.correct: To portray Francie's determination to meet a goal.

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Adib Khorram’s 2018 novel Darius the Great Is Not Okay. Daruis, a teenager from the United States, is visiting his grandparents, Mamou and Babou, and other family members in Iran.

I was too tired to fall all the way asleep, and even though Mamou was soft and warm, leaning up against her wasn’t a terribly comfortable position to sleep in. So I dozed and floated on the clouds of Farsi that blew my way from the front seat of Dayi [Uncle] Jamsheed’s SUV.

It reminded me of when I was little, and Mom chanted to me in Farsi every night before bedtime. It’s hard to describe Farsi chanting: the way Mom drew her voice out like the notes of a cello as she recited poems by Rumi or Hafez. I didn’t know what they meant, but that didn’t matter. It was quiet and soothing.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To name some of the narrator’s favorite poets who wrote in Farsi.

options.name: B
options.content: To describe a situation the narrator thinks is annoying.

options.name: C
options.content: To reveal that the narrator's mother is a poet.

options.name: D
options.content: To connect a current experience to a memory from the narrator’s past.

questions.correct: To connect a current experience to a memory from the narrator’s past.

questions.article: The Old Manse in Concord, Massachusetts, is the house where Nathaniel Hawthorne lived briefly and wrote his short story called Mosses from an Old Manse. Now the house is a museum dedicated to Hawthorne's life and writings. Visitors travel to this museum to feel more connected to an author they admire. To encourage that sense of connection, the museum's curators recommend nearby hiking trails and organize outdoor activities. Such activities help visitors appreciate the natural scenery that inspired Hawthorne.
questions.question: Which choice best states the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It summarizes the career of an author mentioned in the previous sentence.

options.name: B
options.content: It states the current purpose of a building mentioned in the previous sentence.

options.name: C
options.content: It recommends the works of an author mentioned in the previous sentence.

options.name: D
options.content: It recounts the history of a place mentioned in the previous sentence.

questions.correct: It states the current purpose of a building mentioned in the previous sentence.

questions.article: On painter William H. Johnson’s return to the United States in 1938 after a decade in Europe, his style underwent an abrupt transformation. Turning away from landscapes painted in an expressionist style—a style that often involves using fluid distorted shapes and thick textured brushstrokes to express the artist’s subjective experience of reality—Johnson began painting portraits of Black Americans in a bold new way. Evocative of African sculpture and American and Scandinavian folk art, these portraits feature flat, deliberately oversimplified figures in a vibrant but limited color palette.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It elaborates on the previous sentence’s statement about a transitional moment in Johnson’s artistic career.

options.name: B
options.content: It provides information about Johnson’s travels in support of a claim about his artistic influences, which is advanced in the following sentence.

options.name: C
options.content: It recounts a moment in Johnson’s personal life that enabled the success of his subsequent career, which is summarized in the following sentence.

options.name: D
options.content: It presents evidence that calls into questions the previous sentence’s characterization of Johnson’s artistic development.

questions.correct: It elaborates on the previous sentence’s statement about a transitional moment in Johnson’s artistic career.

questions.article: In a study by Mika R. Moran, Daniel A. Rodriguez, and colleagues, residents of Quito, Ecuador, and Bogotá, Colombia, were surveyed about parks in their cities. Of the 618 respondents from Quito, 82.9% indicated that they use the city's parks, and of the 1,121 respondents from Bogotá, 71.9% indicated using city parks. Given that the percentage of Quito respondents who reported living within a 10-minute walk of a park was much lower than that reported by Bogotá respondents, greater proximity alone can't explain the difference in park use.
questions.question: The text makes which point about the difference between the proportions of Quito residents and Bogotá residents using parks?

options.name: A
options.content: It was much larger than the researchers conducting the study expected.

options.name: B
options.content: It was calculated using sources that predate the survey.

options.name: C
options.content: It is caused by something other than the parks' proximity to city residents.

options.name: D
options.content: It could be due to inaccuracies in the survey results.

questions.correct: It is caused by something other than the parks' proximity to city residents.

questions.article: External shopping cues are a type of marketing that uses obvious messaging— a display featuring a new product, for example, or a “buy one, get one free” offer— to entice consumers to make spontaneous purchases. In a study, data scientist Sam K. Hui and colleagues found that this effect can also be achieved with a less obvious cue: rearranging a store's layout. The researchers explain that trying to find items in new locations causes shoppers to move through more of the store, exposing them to more products and increasing the likelihood that they'll buy an item they hadn't planned on purchasing.
questions.question: Which response from a survey given to shoppers who made a purchase at a retail store best supports the researchers' explanation?

options.name: A
options.content: “I needed to buy some cleaning supplies, but they weren't in their regular place. While I was looking for them, I saw this interesting notebook and decided to buy it, too.”

options.name: B
options.content: “I didn't buy everything on my shopping list today. I couldn't find a couple of the items in the store, even though I looked all over for them.”

options.name: C
options.content: “The store sent me a coupon for a new brand of soup, so I came here to find out what kinds of soup that brand offers. I decided to buy a few cans because I had the coupon.”

options.name: D
options.content: “This store is larger than one that's closer to where I live, and it carries more products. I came here to buy some things that the other store doesn't always have.”

questions.correct: “I needed to buy some cleaning supplies, but they weren't in their regular place. While I was looking for them, I saw this interesting notebook and decided to buy it, too.”

questions.article:
Impact of Four Key Industries on Oklahoma Economy in 2017

The Osage Nation, the Quapaw Tribe, and the more than thirty other tribes in Oklahoma operate numerous businesses and generate billions of dollars in revenue. An economics student is researching the tribes' collective activity as a single industry. The student wants to compare the average amount that industry contributed per employee to Oklahoma's economy with the average amount contributed per employee by three other industries. Looking at the table, the student finds the tribal economic activity contributed over $141,000 per employee, on average, ranking it ____
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the comparison?

options.name: A
options.content: above all three of the other industries listed in the table.

options.name: B
options.content: below transportation/warehousing but above both manufacturing and health care.

options.name: C
options.content: above either health care or manufacturing and nearly equal to transportation/warehousing.

options.name: D
options.content: below all three of the other industries listed in the table.

questions.correct: below transportation/warehousing but above both manufacturing and health care.

questions.article: “A Pair of Silk Stockings” is an 1897 short story written by Kate Chopin. In the story, Mrs. Sommers becomes engrossed in the decision of how she should spend a recently obtained sum of money: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from “A Pair of Silk Stockings” most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “The question of investment was one that occupied her greatly. For a day or two she walked about apparently in a dreamy state, but really absorbed in speculation and calculation.”

options.name: B
options.content: “The neighbors sometimes talked of certain ‘better days’ that little Mrs. Sommers had known before she had ever thought of being Mrs. Sommers.”

options.name: C
options.content: “Mrs. Sommers was one who knew the value of bargains; who could stand for hours making her way inch by inch toward the desired object that was selling below cost.”

options.name: D
options.content: “It seemed to her a very large amount of money, and the way in which it stuffed and bulged her worn old porte-monnaie gave her a feeling of importance such as she had not enjoyed for years.”

questions.correct: “The question of investment was one that occupied her greatly. For a day or two she walked about apparently in a dreamy state, but really absorbed in speculation and calculation.”

questions.article: Biologist Rosanna Alegado believes that we might learn how multicellular organisms developed from single-celled ones if we understand why the single-celled organism Salpingoeca rosetta, the oldest living relative of animals, sometimes forms colonies of cells. Alegado and colleagues reviewed data from many studies about how S. rosetta responds when exposed to another type of single-celled organism, bacteria, including Edward G. Ruby's work with Vibrio fischeri bacteria and Ana M. Cerdeño-Tárraga's work with Bacteroides fragilis bacteria. Alegado and colleagues concluded that neither V. fischeri nor B. fragilis are likely to have played a significant role in the development of multicellular organisms.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Alegado and colleagues' conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: S. rosetta tended to form colonies when exposed to V. fischeri and when exposed to B. fragilis.

options.name: B
options.content: S. rosetta tended to form colonies when exposed to V. fischeri, but not when exposed to B. fragilis.

options.name: C
options.content: S. rosetta tended to form colonies when exposed to B. fragilis, but not when exposed to V. fischeri.

options.name: D
options.content: S. rosetta did not tend to form colonies when exposed to either V. fischeri or B. fragilis.

questions.correct: S. rosetta did not tend to form colonies when exposed to either V. fischeri or B. fragilis.

questions.article:
Days per Winter That Lakes Have Surface Ice

It is common for freshwater lakes near or above a latitude of 45° north of the equator, like Lake Mjøsa in Norway, to accumulate surface ice in winter. The amount and duration of ice depends on many factors, including local weather conditions as well as the lake's depth, volume, and surface area, but a climate researcher claims that some lakes in these latitudes have seen a decline in the duration of ice between the early 1980s and the mid-2000s.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data in the table that support the researcher's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Kitusjärvi is at a higher latitude than Lake Monona and typically had more days of ice per winter than Lake Monona did.

options.name: B
options.content: Lake Baikal had more days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980–81.

options.name: C
options.content: Kitusjärvi had fewer days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980–81.

options.name: D
options.content: Kitusjärvi is at a higher latitude than Lake Monona and typically had fewer days of ice per winter than Lake Monona did.

questions.correct: Kitusjärvi had fewer days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980–81.

questions.article: Architects looking for inspiration may examine photographs of iconic buildings such as Angkor Wat in Siem Reap, Cambodia. A two-dimensional photograph, however, cannot capture how a building interacts with its surroundings, whether by complementing, blending in with, or perhaps even clashing with sights and activities nearby. An image of Angkor Wat thus ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: misrepresents how the building is perceived by people who have never visited Siem Reap.

options.name: B
options.content: conceals the subtle deterioration of the building's materials.

options.name: C
options.content: fails to convey the full impact of the building's design and structure.

options.name: D
options.content: serves to exaggerate the building's historical importance.

questions.correct: fails to convey the full impact of the building's design and structure.

questions.article: The Busselton Health Survey (BHS) seeks to discover long-term trends related to public health by compiling and analyzing evidence from approximately 10,000 participants in Australia. As with most longitudinal studies, extensive funding support is needed for BHS to collect the relevant data over timescales and at intervals that will support robust conclusions. But the quality of a more constrained investigation, such as a sociology study seeking only to yield the average age at which people in a given city first become parents, is much less dependent on high levels of funding because ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: such studies are not trying to identify trends over time.

options.name: B
options.content: expanding the scope of such studies is unlikely to be feasible.

options.name: C
options.content: the sociology study is unlikely to be able to recruit 10,000 participants.

options.name: D
options.content: such studies are likely to be a lower priority for funding than BHS.

questions.correct: such studies are not trying to identify trends over time.

questions.article: Anthropologist Livia Barbosa, of the Universidade Federal Fluminense in Brazil, ______ food and sociability in contemporary Brazil—specifically, how foods such as coxinha (a stuffed fried dough) and bolacha sete-capas (a seven-layered wafer) function as central mechanisms in building social relationships, values, and identities.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the convention of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: study

options.name: B
options.content: are studying

options.name: C
options.content: studies

options.name: D
options.content: have studied

questions.correct: studies

questions.article: Writer Silvia Moreno-Garcia’s love of short fiction began when she read a collection of Edgar Allan Poe stories as a child, and she would develop into a prolific short story writer herself, publishing pieces like “Iron Justice versus the Fiends of Evil” (2013) and “Maquech” (2008). Yet she’s best known as a novelist, in part due to her ______ Gothic (2020) earning a spot on the New York Times Best Sellers list.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the convention of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: novel Mexican

options.name: B
options.content: novel: Mexican

options.name: C
options.content: novel, Mexican

options.name: D
options.content: novel (Mexican

questions.correct: novel Mexican

questions.article: At 2,300 to 2,700 years old, General Sherman, a giant sequoia (Sequoiadendron giganteum) located in the United States, is one of the oldest known trees in the world. With over two millennia of climate data in its tree rings, a single tree like this, claims ______ Valerie Trouet, can tell the history of the world.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: dendrochronologist—

options.name: B
options.content: dendrochronologist,

options.name: C
options.content: dendrochronologist

options.name: D
options.content: dendrochronologist:

questions.correct: dendrochronologist

questions.article: Julia Alvarez's 1994 novel In the Time of the Butterflies, a fictionalized account of the lives of the Mirabal ______ can serve as a starting point for those wanting to explore how the rule of dictator Rafael Trujillo has been represented in Dominican American literature.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Sisters, and

options.name: B
options.content: sisters and

options.name: C
options.content: sisters,

options.name: D
options.content: sisters

questions.correct: sisters,

questions.article: Scholars have praised Gwendolyn Brooks's 1949 poem “Matthew Cole” for its nuanced portrayal of life in Brooks's South Side Chicago neighborhood. The poem shouldn't be regarded as being simply a product of Brooks's ______ the breadth of the poet's influences, which range from medieval English ballads to the poetry of Countee Cullen and Emily Dickinson.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: surroundings, though, considering

options.name: B
options.content: surroundings, though. Considering

options.name: C
options.content: surroundings; though, considering

options.name: D
options.content: surroundings, though; considering

questions.correct: surroundings, though, considering

questions.article: Sociologist Alton Okinaka sits on the review board tasked with adding new sites to the Hawai'i Register of Historic Places, which includes the Wailuku School, built in 1904, and the Kaua’i Belt Road, a section of Route 560 along the north coast. Okinaka doesn't make such decisions single-handedly, ______ historical designations must be approved by a group of nine other experts.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: however. All

options.name: B
options.content: however all

options.name: C
options.content: however, all

options.name: D
options.content: however and all

questions.correct: however. All

questions.article: After appropriate permissions are granted, a typical archaeological dig begins with a surveyor making a detailed grid of the excavation site. Then, the site is carefully dug, and any artifacts found are recorded and mapped onto the site grid. ______ the artifacts are removed, cataloged, and analyzed in a laboratory.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For instance,

options.name: B
options.content: On the contrary,

options.name: C
options.content: Earlier,

options.name: D
options.content: Finally,

questions.correct: Finally,

questions.article: To guarantee the validity of experimental results, scientists rely on precise, unchanging standards of measurement. ______ metrologists (scientists who study measurement) developed the SI, or International System of Units. The SI's units of measurement are based on unchanging values in nature, such as the mass of an electron or the speed of light.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: In contrast,

options.name: B
options.content: Regardless,

options.name: C
options.content: In addition,

options.name: D
options.content: For this reason,

questions.correct: For this reason,

questions.article: Soil polluted with nickel (a heavy metal) is harmful to many plants and animals, but the plant species Pistia stratiotes, or water lettuce, not only thrives in such conditions but also helps remediate them. As a metal hyperaccumulator, Pistia stratiotes absorbs a large amount of nickel and stores it safely in its roots and shoots; ______ nickel concentrations in the soil decrease.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: in turn,

options.name: B
options.content: nevertheless,

options.name: C
options.content: specifically,

options.name: D
options.content: in addition,

questions.correct: in turn,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Iranian scholar Abu Rayhan al-Biruni studied Earth's physical features.
  • He theorized that a large landmass existed west of Europe and east of Asia.
  • Al-Biruni published his landmass theory in 1037 CE.
questions.question: The student wants to specify when al-Biruni published his landmass theory. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In 1037 CE, al-Biruni published his theory that a large landmass existed west of Europe and east of Asia.

options.name: B
options.content: Al-Biruni, who studied Earth's physical features, published a theory about a large landmass.

options.name: C
options.content: Al-Biruni was an Iranian scholar who studied Earth's physical features.

options.name: D
options.content: An Iranian scholar who studied Earth's physical features, al-Biruni theorized that a large landmass existed west of Europe and east of Asia.

questions.correct: In 1037 CE, al-Biruni published his theory that a large landmass existed west of Europe and east of Asia.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Birds of Northern South America is an identification guidebook by ornithologists Robin Restall, Clemencia Rodner, and Miguel Lentino.
  • It lists the thirty-five hummingbird species found in Suriname.
  • The long-billed starthroat is a large hummingbird found in Suriname.
  • It is identifiable by its turquoise crown and its very long, black, straight bill.
  • The ruby-topaz hummingbird is a small hummingbird found in Suriname.
  • It is identifiable by its crimson crown and its short, black, curved bill.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize a difference between the two birds?

options.name: A
options.content: Though they share several traits in common, the long-billed starthroat is larger than the ruby-topaz hummingbird.

options.name: B
options.content: Identifiable by its very long, black, straight bill and its turquoise crown, the long-billed starthroat is a large hummingbird found in Suriname.

options.name: C
options.content: The long-billed starthroat and the ruby-topaz hummingbird are two of the thirty-five hummingbird species found in Suriname.

options.name: D
options.content: The ruby-topaz hummingbird is a small hummingbird identifiable by its crimson crown and its short, black, curved bill.

questions.correct: Though they share several traits in common, the long-billed starthroat is larger than the ruby-topaz hummingbird.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Czech Technical University in Prague, the Czech Republic, is home to a Foucault pendulum.
  • The pendulum consists of a weighted ball that swings at the end of a roughly 21-meter-long cable.
  • Like all Foucault pendulums, it dangles from a fixed point that ensures the swing path of the pendulum doesn't change.
  • To an observer, the swing path of a Foucault pendulum appears to change over time because Earth rotates beneath it.
  • Foucault pendulums are used as a simple way to provide evidence of Earth's rotation.
questions.question: The student wants to explain how a Foucault pendulum provides evidence of Earth’s rotation. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In Prague, the Czech Republic, a Foucault pendulum at Czech Technical University provides evidence of Earth's rotation.

options.name: B
options.content: Though it swings on an unchanging path, a Foucault pendulum appears to change its swing path over time because Earth rotates beneath it.

options.name: C
options.content: A Foucault pendulum, which consists of a weighted ball at the end of a long cable, provides evidence of Earth's rotation.

options.name: D
options.content: The Foucault pendulum at Czech Technical University in Prague, the Czech Republic, swings on an unchanging path, but Earth rotates beneath it.

questions.correct: Though it swings on an unchanging path, a Foucault pendulum appears to change its swing path over time because Earth rotates beneath it.
